choices.D: The supplicant creates RADIUS packets and sends them to the authenticator, which encapsulates them into EAP and forwards them to the authentication server.

The firewall permits IPv6 and IPv4 traffic from higher security interfaces to lower security interfaces without an ACL.
choices.B: The firewall permits Layer 3 traffic from lower security interfaces to higher security interfaces if a standard ACL is configured on the lower security interface.
choices.D: The firewall requires ARPs to be inspected before they are allowed through the firewall.
choices.C: The firewall permits broadcast and multicast traffic from higher security interfaces to lower security interfaces without an ACL.

questions.question_text: How does the transparent firewall process traffic through the ASA?

discussion.content:
Allowing Layer 3 Traffic

 Unicast IPv4 and IPv6 traffic is allowed through the bridge group automatically from a higher security interface to a lower security interface, without an access rule.

 For Layer 3 traffic traveling from a low to a high security interface, an access rule is required on the low security interface.

 ARPs are allowed through the bridge group in both directions without an access rule. ARP traffic can be controlled by ARP inspection.

 IPv6 neighbor discovery and router solicitation packets can be passed using access rules.

 Broadcast and multicast traffic can be passed using access rules.

The answer is A.
Standard ACLs cannot be applied to interfaces to control traffic.
For routed mode, the following types of traffic are allowed through by default:
- Unicast IPv4 traffic from a higher security interface to a lower security interface.
- Unicast IPv6 traffic from a higher security interface to a lower security interface.
For transparent mode, the following types of traffic are allowed through by default:
- ARPs in both directions.
- BPDUs in both directions.
- Unicast IPv4 traffic from a higher security interface to a lower security interface.
- Unicast IPv6 traffic from a higher security interface to a lower security interface.

questions.question_text: Which network topology describes multiple LANs in a geographically limited area?

discussion.content:
A
A campus area network (CAN) is a network of multiple interconnected local area networks (LAN) in a limited geographical area. A CAN is smaller than a wide area network (WAN) or metropolitan area network (MAN). A CAN is also known as a corporate area network (CAN)
https://www.examguides.com/CCNA-Security/ccna-security-4.htm

comments.content: I also tend to answer CAN, although the information on the Internet is contradictory, and what cisco meant is hard to guess.

The answer is A max number of method lists is 4

Correct answer is A.
At least one method must be specified. To use the local user database, use the local keyword. A single list can contain up to four methods, which are tried in order, from left to right.
